>
[...]
> Now, if you want to "white box test", that's a very different (and
> interesting) question.

If you want to do white-box testing, I'd suggest that you follow the concept
of mathematical induction (which underlies recursion, of course):

* Do test cases for the base cases, i.e., the non-recursive code parts.

* Do test cases for the "induction case", i.e., all branches with recursion.


The latter will, by necessity, also test at least some base cases - but
those should be separately tested, as recursion problems and base case
problems are usually very different.

Also, with recursive code, I feel often better when I add assertions stating
the invariants inside the methods than "only" testing them from outside -
this explicit (more or less) mathematical approach also often yields either
corrections of the code or at least improvements (reduction or clarification
of cases) - in some cases both.

Regards
Harald M.
